name: silicon carbide production | silicon carbide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9258/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of silicon carbide. Silicon carbide (SiC) is a ceramic compound of silicon and carbon that is manufactured on a large scale for use mainly as an abrasive but also occurs in nature as the extremely rare mineral moissanite. Silicon carbide is used during wafer sawing. Other possible uses are:;- Abrasive for grinding, cutting and polishing ;- Ceramic and refractory products;- Filler in metals, plastics and building material;This dataset is based on data from literature.;References:;Jungbluth N., Stucki M, and Frischknecht R. (2009) Photovoltaics. In Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. ecoinvent report No. 6-XII, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, 2009.;Liethschmidt, K. and Garbes, J. 2008. Silicon Carbide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Gendorf (2016) Umwelterklärung 2015, Werk Gendorf Industriepark, www.gendorf.de.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends with the production of silicon carbide. The dataset includes raw materials and electricity use, as well as some emissions to air from the process.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2391:Manufacture of refractory products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time of publication. Some values are based on data published by the Gendorf factory that were collected between 2011 and 2015. The time period has been adjusted accordingly. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Estimation for Europe. Emissions data from a plant in NL. Some values are based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. These are assumed to be valid for this geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Silicon carbide is manufactured through reaction of silicon dioxide and carbon, yielding silicon carbide and carbon monoxide. This dataset represents the average technology used by 4 companies.;Reference:;Liethschmidt, K. and Garbes, J. 2008. Silicon Carbide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Emission data extrapolated with total CO2 emissions.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data from literature and the internet. Average data from 4 companies. Some values are calculated based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.

exchanges.description:
Silicon carbide (SiC) is a ceramic compound of silicon and carbon that is manufactured on a large scale for use mainly as an abrasive but also occurs in nature as the extremely rare mineral moissanite. Silicon carbide is used during wafer sawing. Other possible uses are:
- Abrasive for grinding, cutting and polishing 
- Ceramic and refractory products
- Filler in metals, plastics and building material

References:
Jungbluth N., Stucki M, and Frischknecht R. (2009) Photovoltaics. In Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. ecoinvent report No. 6-XII, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, 2009.
Liethschmidt, K. and Garbes, J. 2008. Silicon Carbide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. This value is a 5-year average of data (2011 - 2015) published by the Gendorf factory (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de),  (Gendorf, 2015, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de),  (Gendorf, 2014, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The amount of nitrogen used per kg of chemical substance produced is calculated using literature data published by the Gendorf factory based in Germany, which produces a wide range of chemical substances. The factory produced 1657400 tonnes of chemical substances in the year 2015 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de) and 740000 tonnes of intermediate products. The reported amount of nitrogen used in 2015 was 33512400 Nm3 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). One Nm3 of nitrogen is equal to 1.2506 kg. The resulting amount of nitrogen - the 5-year average (2011 - 2015, weighted by production volume) is 0.019 kg/kg. Nitrogen is mainly used during the production of chemicals for 'blanketing', which is the process of applying gas to the vapour space of a container or vessel in order to control its composition.
